"Kiba said you needed a Hyuga," said Ninata as she knelt down. "So I came as fast as I could." Wait, that came out wrong. "Er, as in, I got here as fast as I could, not..." A crash shook her as the fight between Chouji and the monsters intensified. She resisted the urge to focus her spherical vision on him, knowing that she wouldn't like what she saw.

"Have you seen an archer anywhere on the way here?" said Shikamaru, clearly not caring about her unfortunate use of words.

Ninata nodded. "Yeah. I caught a glimpse of him just before I found you. And I nearly got shot in the process."

"So he's seen you," said Shikamaru with a sigh. "And chances are, you've lured him straight to us."

Ninata felt the blood drain from her face. Crap, she screwed up. She screwed up bad. "Oh. Oh no."

"Forget about it!" Shikamaru barked. "Can you see him now?"

"Gimme a second," said Ninata. Turning her focus away from Shikamaru, she extended her vision outward to the trees all around them. She saw Chouji bleeding and breathing heavily on his hands and knees before he popped a pill into his mouth and stood back up with renewed vigor against the trio of monsters overpowering him. She saw a lone Sound-nin sitting idly on a tree branch playing a flute, with vermillion skin and demonic horns sprouting up from her long mane of fiery pink hair. She saw endless trees with green leaves rustling in the wind. And she saw a strange, tanned, inhuman thing with more arms than a person had any right to possess part some leaves away as it strung a massive arrow, bigger than any of the others she had seen that day, on an even larger bow that was poised in her direction.

"I see him," said Ninata, her blood running cold. "And he sees us, and he's arming a bow! Quick, we have to-"

A sudden chill came over the former boy, and in instant, she was out.

Shikamaru nodded. "The fighting stopped after you knocked half the forest down, so hopefully, the Doki are down too."

Ninata activated her Byakugan. "I don't see them anywhere around here. But I do see Chouji, and...he doesn't look good."

Shikamaru's normally unflappable exterior broke as a wave of fear and concern washed over his face "Damn it," he whispered, getting up to no doubt rush to his friend.

"You're right," he said. "Ninata, you're with me. Stay behind me, keep your Byakugan up, and tell me if you see anything. Ino, you check up on Chouji. Give him all the medical care you can. He was straining hard, his face only barely masking the pain he had to feel maintaining the jutsu like that while wounded.

Sakon continued. "But as soon as he lets up on it–and he will very soon, mark my words–we'll deal with the both of you very handily. Just as we did with your friend and his little dog too."

"Kiba?" said Ninata, feeling her heart skip a beat. "What do you mean? What did you do to him?"

"You've already lost," said Shikamaru calmly, clearly taking control of the conversation. "Your friends are all dead, and the rest of mine are coming right now as we speak. You can't take us all at once, and we've just about rescued Sasuke. It's over."

But Sakon nearly grinned, letting out a hushed chortle at the ponytailed boy's bluff. "Rescued? Is that what this is all about? You think that you're saving your precious Uchiha from a kidnapping? We didn't force Sasuke into anything; he joined us of our own free will!"
1212222211121121222121122222112212111221.title: Finding Sasuke

1212222211121121222121122222112212111221.content:
Ninata tightened her hold on the kunai. "You're lying!"

"Your little heartthrob feels nothing for you or for your worthless village!" the dominant twin cackled. "He accepted our invitation to come to Otogakure as Orochimaru's latest student, and took his offer of power without any convincing on our part."

"You're LYING!" Ninata screamed. "Sasuke's a jerk, but he'd never willingly go with you bastards!"

Shikamaru cast a confused sidelong glance at Ninata, but said nothing. Sakon only laughed some more.

"Believe what you want. But this 'rescue operation' of yours was doomed from the start."

"Sakon," Ukon whispered. "Don't goad her. She might–"

"No need to worry," said Sakon. "Our little birdie's about to hatch."

"Huh?" said Ninata as she glanced behind her. She caught only a small glimpse of the taru before an explosion of what could only be described as black fire flooded her vision and sent her hurdling up in the air and into a tree. The force knocked the wind out of her and sent shocks of agonizing pain into her two breasts as they smashed and scraped into the rough back. From the corner of her vision, she saw Shikamaru drop his readied stance as his concentration puffed away and his shadow jutsu ended. Now free of the boy's hold on him, the conjoined ninjas leaped at the Nara and sent him spinning to the ground with a backhanded slap to the head. He did not get up.

"No," Ninata mumbled. She was hurting all over and her lungs burned with desperate need for oxygen. She didn't have time to recover, she had to get up and–

A hand clamped down on her throat. The former boy felt her body pull upward until it no longer touched the ground. And the next thing she knew, she was staring directly into the hateful eyes of Sakon. No...not again!

"What's wrong?" said Sakon with an evil smirk. "Don't have any more tricks? No more red chakra? Come, we're all waiting to see what you can do, bitch."

"Stop dawdling and just kill her!" barked Ukon, his voice strained. Whatever he had gone through previously, he was still recovering from it.

"If she tries anything, I'll just snap her neck." To demonstrate this, he squeezed Ninata's throat. The girl, already short of breath, choked and gasped, her lungs desperate for air. His point made, Sakon eased up his hold, giving the blunette a chance to breathe again. "But first..."

Ninata's vision was all a blur. She could barely make anything out. And she was too weak and tired to do anything. She was too weak and tired to even think. But she caught something. She saw a figure, cloaked in black, stand up on shaky legs like a newborn foal, and shake off a dreadful mixture of liquid darkness as if it was afterbirth. Wings sprouted from its back like a demon of western lore before it took to the air, flew into the sky, and circled around the canopy of the forest as if it was testing its new appendages out for the first time. It then veered its way down in her direction, landing feet-first right in front of her, and chilling her body with a gust of wing as it buffeted its wings one last time.

The transformed Hyuga gazed at the figure, willing her vision to sharpen so she could make out who or what exactly it was. It was alien, with granite skin, violet lips, and a cross-like symbol etched into the middle of its face. Looking deep into the blood-red irises of its eyes that spun with the familiar sickle-like shapes of the Sharingan, Ninata quickly realized just who she was looking at.

"Sas...uke?" she moaned weakly. It was all she could get out, but inwardly, she was all but screaming: What the hell happened to you?

"Do you know this girl?" said Sakon, all traces of black humor gone from his voice.

Sasuke gave only the faintest hint of a head shake. "Just her name," he said, his voice deeper and graver than Ninata remembered. He spoke with absolutely no emotion, save for maybe a hint of disappointment, as if he was expecting to see someone else. "Hyuga Hinata. She means nothing to me."

"Means nothing, hm?" said Sakon, his mouth forming a horizontal line. "Strange, she seemed really interested in you. No matter. Since she clearly means absolutely nothing to you, you'll have no qualms against killing her then? As a test of loyalty to your new master, Orochimaru?"

Ninata couldn't move, but she could feel her heart thump into her chest. He wouldn't...
1212222211121121222121122222112212111221.title: Transformed Eye to Transformed Eye

1212222211121121222121122222112212111221.content:
Sasuke once again shook his head in the faintest way possible. "No. I wouldn't."

Panic seized Ninata's heart. "Sasuke...don't...!"

Electricity wreathed around his left hand.

"Don't...please!"

The song of a thousand birds reverberated across the forest.

======

Hinata cut through the woods like a knife in the wind, her arms flailing behind her. She had taken off the very second Tenten was stable and securely hidden, wanting nothing more than to be reunited with her love. Tenten had been kind enough to lend her a shirt before she left though, which they both figured the younger girl was in greater need of. It was a little long on her small frame, but that was okay; it just meant more coverage for her otherwise bare bottom. She wasn't about to complain about finally having some decency, though she had to admit feeling a little weird to have any kind of clothing on after being naked for so long outside of bed.

Her Byakugan active, Hinata traced the path she hoped Ninata had taken, working her way in the direction that Shikamaru and Ino had last been seen in. Her enhanced vision allowed her to literally see the forest through the trees, and sure enough, she picked up on a clearing just ahead of her. And lo and behold, the blunette caught sight of Ino, who looked to be rushing ahead in a fright.

What is she in a hurry for?

In three bounds, Hinata got her answer when she saw the conjoined Sound twins, holding her naked lover up by the neck! Her heart just about leapt into her throat. How did he...when did...no! And standing before them was a demonic winged figure that looked kind of, sort of, vaguely like Sasuke. But wrong. Very, very wrong.

Worse, his arm was thrust straight into Ninata!

======

And just like that, it was over. The naked, lavender-eyed girl with the hot bod was dead. Impaled by her fellow Leaf-nin. Sakon would have preferred a more drawn-out death; hell, he still got hard at the thought of pinning her to the ground and getting a taste at all her supple flesh had to offer. But he supposed watching her die by Sasuke's hand would have to do.

I'll just have to make sure to give her twin sister the treatment they both deserve.

"Very well," he said, locking his eyes onto the Uchiha's to see if he could sense any kind of latent emotion from the raven-haired boy. Shock, guilt, sorrow, doubt, or anything really. But all he got was a blank and unreadable expression. "Your loyalty to Orochimaru is proven and your ties to Konohagakure are well and truly severed. Now we can–"

He didn't get to finish that thought as a familiar heat began to wash over him from the girl's slumped form. It started off like the warmth of a small candle, but rapidly boiled into a fire that was rapidly going out of control. Instinctively, he released his hold on her neck and leaped back.

It can't be.

The girl's hand seized the shocked Uchiha's arm, even as it was still impaled through her torso and protruding sickly out of her back, his fist red with her blood. The boy, still looking like an unholy imitation of a tengu, struggled to pull his hand out of her grip, his previously stoic face twisting into mild panic as his efforts proved useless against the girl who by all rights should not be physically capable of standing!

A low hiss escaped from her lips as she slowly, agonizingly pulled Sasuke's arm out of her torso, the action making a sickening wet slurping sound as corrupted flesh rubbed against naked muscle and torn viscera. The Uchiha's eyes widened as it quickly dawned on him that there was absolutely nothing he could do. He could only gape in terror.

And then the girl hurled his body into the nearest tree.

A small tremble shook Sakon as his brother drew in a sharp breath behind him.

The Hyuga girl kept her gaze locked on the Uchiha boy. She took one step forward, her whole body lurching from the sudden mass of missing matter in her form. A cloak of crimson chakra enveloped her body, the same kind that the twins had seen in their last altercation with her. And they watched in complete wonder, as the gaping hole where her stomach was began to close. Muscle and fat seemingly bubbled and melted like wax as tissue was reformed, torn blood vessels were reconnected, fractured bones were realigned, and ruptured organs inflated and pulsed again with life-giving fluid.

"Ssssaaasss...ukeee," the girl snarled, her voice a dangerous octave lower and seething with unbridled hatred.

"Sakon," said Ukon with absolute certainty. "We have to go."

Sakon merely nodded. For once, he was in complete agreement with his more practical brother. He didn't know what the hell this...thing was, but he was absolutely certain that there was no way he could defeat it. Not alone and not now. He dashed to Sasuke, who was starting to pull himself out of the tree he was all but embedded in.

"Get up!" he commanded. "We're leaving. Now!"

The boy glared at him stubbornly. "But–"

"You can't beat this thing," said Ukon. "Not as you are now. We can escape while it's still recovering. But we will lose if we fight it now."

"What the hell is she?" said Sasuke.

Sakon turned to the Hyuga girl, and saw her face for the first time. The soft childish naiveté that it originally bore was gone. In its place was the ugly grimace of a wild animal no longer capable of rational thought, with sharp bestial fangs jutting out of her mouth, and the large orbs of her eyes now a blazing red, like two angry blood moons hanging in the sky. Nothing was capable of doing that. Nothing except...

"A Jinchūriki," said Ukon in the lowest of whispers.
1212222211121121222121122222112212111221.title: Crossing the Line

1212222211121121222121122222112212111221.content:
Red. Endless red. She had the most powerful eyes on the planet, and all she could see before her was a blood-hued mist that stretched on forever. A blood-hued mist that drowned everything, choked the life out of world, save for the only things that mattered: the shadowy shapes of the ones she was going to kill.

Kill kill kill...

Her body burned, inside and out, but she welcomed the pain. The air was thick and threatened to crush her under its sheer weight, but she welcomed the burden. Her breath was ragged and it tasted of salt, iron and copper, but she welcomed that too. She would suffer any agony if it meant she would hold their three heads in her claws.

A cloud the color of congealed blood flooded her vision as the two-headed demon of sound hurled an object upon the earth. She knew what that meant. They were running, trying to get away within a cloud of smoke. She would not let that happen. She'd rip them limb from limb before she'd let that happen! She'd flay the flesh off their backs, devour their hearts, tear their tongues, gouge out their eyes...

...kill kill kill...

She gave chase, cutting through the smoke that threatened to blind her. She would find them. By every unholy spirit that had ever been conceived, she would find them, and give them their due reward. Her nerves erupted with heat until it felt as though pure magma was pumping through her veins, but she ignored it. She would gladly burn all her flesh away to see the look in their eyes as she snuffed their lives out, one by one.

...kill kill kill...

She stumbled. She tripped. She fell. She crashed upon the forest floor. And just like that, the energy within her body left her. Dissipated, like a candle with no more wax to burn. And in the distance, beyond the reach of her talons, in the crimson-hued fog that clouded her sight, she saw their flickering forms growing ever smaller in the rustling leaves of the forest.

...won't...get...away...

"...nata!" She thought she heard a voice call her name. A familiar voice, as gentle and soothing as the soft pattering of rain on a koi pond.

Who is that?

Her vision blurred, but she thought she saw a face enter her vision. A beautiful face, angelic and heart-shaped, with two large orbs of silver that glowed softly through the crimson haze like pearls from the bluest ocean.

I know her.

"Ninata!" the girl cried, her voice panicked, fearful and growing more and more distant to her ears. "Ninata!"

Her vision went black. She heard nothing more.

=====

Beep.

Beep.

Beep.

Beep.

Beep.

Ninata opened her eyes to the sound of electronic hums and computerized blips. A stretch of harsh, florescent light shone coldly upon her from above. White stretched on every which way she looked, bright, blank and lifeless.

Am I...dead?

She pushed herself up to a sitting position, only to clutch her head as a wave of dizziness and stinging pain suddenly washed over it. A blast of cool air hit the skin of her bare breasts as some kind of soft fabric fell off her chest, but she couldn't be bothered to care. This throbbing pain...it was the worst headache she ever experienced.

Guess that means I'm alive then.

The former boy slowly looked around, her hand still massaging her ailing head. She was on a bed of some sort, narrow and just as uncannily white as everything else in the room, with all sorts of tubes sticking into her and an ICU monitor displaying her heart rate to the side. She blinked in confusion. A...hospital? When did I get here?

Ninata shut her eyes in concentration as she attempted to retrace her steps and figure out how she got here. She was in the forest, training with Hinata, learning how to make use of her new bloodline ability. They took off their clothes, danced naked on the river, splashed around. Then they swam to the shore, both ready to make love on the bank, when they suddenly saw their fellow Leaf-nin in hot pursuit of the Sound who had taken Sasuke. She and her girlfriend joined them. They got into many fights and dangerous encounters. At the end of it all, she was staring directly into Sasuke's eyes. But he didn't look like himself; he looked like some kind of monster from legend. And then, while she was helpless, a thousand birds began to sing and then he...he...

"That can't be true," she said, her lips just barely mouthing the words. "He wouldn't have. It doesn't make sense. He...I..."

Ninata's thoughts were interrupted by a harsh voice cutting through the air like a sharpened katana. "You are an idiot." The transformed Hyuga girl broke away from her reverie and brought her attention to the doorway where Tsunade stood, arms crossed and brows lowered to form a disapproving glare directed at her.

"Obaa-chan?"

"You are an idiot," Tsunade repeated, stepping into the room and closing the door behind her, quietly so as to not disturb any other patients, but also with an air of authority that told the younger girl that there would be no escape. The short-tempered drunken gambler that Ninata knew was gone, replaced by a woman of steel who had been selected to be the Leaf's fifth Hokage for a very good reason. "You are in a significantly weakened state, in a body you don't know how to control, not even an official ninja, who threw yourself into a military operation unarmed and...undressed!" She punctuated that last point with a tug on Ninata's blanket, raising it up from where it was piled at the girl's waist so as to cover her still naked body. "What the hell were you thinking?!"

Ninata winced at the Hokage's words as she clutched the hospital blanket to her chest, the older woman's every syllable penetrating the transformed Hyuga like a stab to the heart. "I...I just wanted to..." she trailed off, not quite knowing what to say or how to explain herself, her adrenaline starting to run too high to give her a chance to think clearly.

"Yes, I know what you wanted to do. You wanted to show off your new power and strut your stuff like a peacock in a mission you were to have no part in. All the while never once conceiving that your current state would make you a liability in the field and possibly get people killed!"

"I...provided some help!" Ninata cried, looking up at the Hokage with watery eyes. "I helped save Shikamaru and Ino and Chouji, didn't I? And Hinata, she saved Tenten. I wasn't...I wasn't totally useless. Was I?" Suddenly, her eyes widened. She didn't recall seeing Hinata after they ran unto the bun-haired girl. "Is...is Hinata-chan all right?"

Tsunade sighed as she pulled up a chair to sit beside the former Uzumaki's bed. "Hinata's fine," she said, her tone softening up, but still keeping its razor edge. "She was actually one of the few who got through this disaster unharmed, in fact. She was absolutely hysterical when my men found her and the rest of the team in the woods, and we had to just about pry her away from you. I sent her home to your shared apartment, in case you're wondering. I'll be sure to inform her that you've awakened."

Ninata let out the breath she didn't realize she was holding. Hinata-chan was safe. That was good. "So how long have I been out?"

"You've been unconscious for a little over a day. Somewhere within the realm of 35 hours. Your chakra levels were dangerously low, and your coils were...Ninata, to be perfectly honest, what I saw of them was one of the worst cases of interior chakra burning I had ever seen in a person. What the hell did you do?"

"Um, well," Ninata said, licking her lips nervously. "That...that happened when I was forced to call on the Kyubey's chakra. Turned out my new coils were a little too...small for it I guess. That's what I got from Hinata-chan anyway."

"Should have thought as much," said the Hokage, kneading a finger into the diamond-shaped mark on her forehead. "Well, you'll live, that's important. But if we didn't have you hooked up on so many pain killers right now, I don't think you'd be in a position to speak right now. And don't think about leaving this hospital for the next week."

Ninata wordlessly nodded at that. "Did we...was the mission successful at least?"

Tsunade shook her head. "No. Hinata and Ino reported seeing Sasuke leaving the borders of Konoha's territory accompanied by a Sound-nin. With everyone else indisposed of, and it being quite clear that this was no longer a rescue operation as we were led to believe, they concluded it was not to their advantage to continue pursuit. The mission was a failure."

"Ohhhh," said Ninata, lowering her head despondently. They failed. She failed. The Sound won again. They got what they wanted, and now they had her friend in their clutches.

Friend? Could she even call Sasuke that anymore? She knew he was a jerk, he always got on her nerves, and they weren't exactly on the best of terms in recent times, but...but...Ninata's mind drew a blank. All she could see anymore was that twisted inhuman mask he wore, devoid of all emotion as he thrust an electrified fist into...why did he do it? Why did he betray his village? What was going on in his head? Why...was he willing to kill her? No, it wasn't me he was willing to kill. It was Hinata-chan. He thought I was Hinata-chan. He was willing to kill her, and he would have without a second thought. If he ever did anything to hurt her, I'd...I'd...

"Ninata?" Tsunade asked, her voice filling with concern. Ninata snapped back to the present and noticed that the palms of her hands were slightly damp and stinging in pain. She had clenched her fists so tightly into them, that her nails had drawn blood.

"I-I'm sorry," the former boy sputtered as she loosened her hands and laid down, blushing with embarrassment that she had almost let her temper get a hold of her. "Just...tell me, how is everyone else? Did everyone...make it out okay?"
1212222211121121222121122222112212111221.title: Failure

1212222211121121222121122222112212111221.content:
"Hinata is perfectly fine, as I explained before," said Tsunade. "As is Ino. Both of them survived with only minor cuts and bruises. Shikamaru suffered a deep cut and a concussion, but he'll be ready for active duty soon enough. Tenten is alive, in no small part thanks to Hinata, but her leg will require surgery before she can return to the field. She'll be recovering alongside her teammate, Lee, whose operation I just completed yesterday."

There was a momentary pause. "And the rest?" said Ninata.

Tsunade closed her eyes and sighed. That was never a good sign in Ninata's experience. "Chouji suffered many severe injuries–which I will not go into at this time–and a massive drain to his chakra reserves. He's comatose and in intensive care now, and nobody has any idea when, or if, he will ever wake up. As for Kiba...Kiba is..."

There was another pause. Ninata couldn't help but fidget uncomfortably in the silence. "Yes? What happened to Kiba?" she asked, though she had a feeling she already knew the answer.

The Hokage's words were soft, but to Ninata's ears, they might as well have been a thunderclap. "Kiba is dead."

A tangible silence fell over the room, so thick it was almost suffocating. Ninata took a few deep, measured breaths as the older woman's words echoed in her head, an exercise she had been taught to stay calm and steady in the wake of extreme distress. Kiba was dead. A boy not much older than her, who she had grown up alongside for most of her young life. He was strong, healthy, determined and ready to fight the last time she saw him. And now...

Ninata couldn't say she would necessarily miss the dog boy. She didn't hate him per se, but she didn't really know him all that well either. And what little she did know was not very positive. She wouldn't beat around the bush; Kiba was a jerk, one of among many children whose taunts and jeers made her life in the academy a living hell. But Kiba was Hinata's friend, and Hinata, true to her kind heart, had nothing but good things to say about both him and his dog. She often said that he was like the older brother she always wished she had. The older brother she wished she had...without estranging.

Hinata didn't have that older brother. Not anymore. And Ninata would never get to know or see that side of him. The former Uzumaki may not have liked Kiba personally, but she knew she wasn't one to hold a grudge either. Maybe if they had a chance to actually talk and spar like two equals, they could have been friends. But it was too late for that now. And Ninata knew why.

It was because of her. It was because she was weak. It was because she didn't have the strength to kill that bastard Sakon when she had the chance. It was because she was barely able to stand when Kiba showed up in the nick of time to save her and Hinata. If Ninata hadn't been there, then he wouldn't have needed to save them. Maybe, just maybe, he'd still be alive...

The former Uzumaki rolled to her side. She couldn't bear to look the Hokage in the eye. She didn't deserve to. Trash like her didn't even deserve to be in the same room as a ninja so powerful.

"You blame yourself," said the Hokage. It wasn't a question. "I suppose on some level, you should. Ninata, what you did was grossly irresponsible. You were not ready for that kind of combat situation and it will be some time before you ever are. And you most certainly were not prepared or equipped for it. I don't doubt that you meant well, but whether you knew it or not, your presence in the mission affected things, and probably not for the better. If you hadn't been there, then things might have gone differently. Maybe it would have succeeded. Maybe we would have Sasuke here in our custody. Maybe everyone I sent would have come home alive and in once piece."

"You don't need to rub it in," Ninata murmured, her normally chipper voice sounding so deflated, even to her own ears.

Tsunade continued. "Or maybe...maybe everyone would have died if you weren't there. Maybe if you and Hinata hadn't intervened, then we'd be carving several more names on the monument. I heard the reports from Shikamaru, Ino, Tenten, and Hinata. I won't deny that you two did some good out there. And I won't deny that the responsibility for this failure rests on the shoulders of many people, not just you. But that doesn't change the fact that both you and Hinata were reckless. And if either of you continue this kind of behavior, you will eventually get yourselves or someone else killed."

Ninata's eyes widened at the mention of Hinata's name. "Wait!" she gasped, turning her attention back to Tsunade. "Hinata-chan did nothing wrong. Joining Shikamaru and the others was all my idea! She tried to talk me out of it. It was my fault!"

"Hinata may have been reluctant," said Tsunade as she crossed her arms, "but she is every capable of making her own choices, and she still followed you in this fool's errand. She understood the risks, she understood that what you and she were doing was not smart, and she did it anyway. She let you commit this foolishness, and for that, she bears just as much responsibility as you."

"Please, don't punish her," Ninata whispered. "She doesn't deserve this. Not after...Kiba..." The former boy would take anything the older woman could throw at her. Beatings, demotions, community service, dishonorable discharge, she could handle it. She'd accept it. It's what she deserved after all. But if Hinata suffered in any way due to Ninata's fuck-ups...she didn't think she'd ever be able to forgive herself.

"I've already had this talk with her," said Tsunade. "And she understands precisely where she failed. As for what I'm going to do with you two...I haven't decided yet."

Ninata moaned as she turned away from the Hokage again, the weight of her actions really coming down on her now. Every test she failed in the academy, every lowly D-rank mission she botched, none of them could approach the magnitude of this latest screw-up of hers. She couldn't do anything right, she failed every task she took up, failed every person who depended on her. How could Hinata ever love a worthless cur like her? Would she even continue to love her after this?

Tsunade sighed again, her voice beginning to soften to a more motherly tone, the anger that had been coursing through her veins finally burning out. "Ninata, I'm not...I'm not trying to kick you while you're down. Or Hinata. A lot has happened in such a short time, I understand that, especially in the wake of this transformation you've undergone that we're still trying to wrap out heads around. I only want you to...understand. There's more to being a good ninja than just leaping into every fray you come across. You might think it's your sworn duty to risk everything you have for your people, and that's admirable. But you need to understand your limits too, know what you can do and what you can't. Something I'm starting to think your instructor never bothered to teach you.

"I worry about you, you know," she added, her voice almost dropping to a whisper. She paused for a moment, as if to hear what Ninata had to say. But for once in the young loudmouth's life, she had nothing. When that became clear to the blonde, she stood up, knowing that the discussion had run its course. "We'll talk later. Until then, just rest. That's an order."

Tsunade tenderly ran a hand through the younger girl's dark locks, clearly as a sign of comfort. But Ninata found no peace from the gesture. It only reminded her of how Hinata would lovingly caress her after the two of them shared an intense orgasm. She'll never want to touch me again after this. Ever.

The lights flickered off and the door closed once more, leaving Ninata alone with her thoughts. And a steadily growing ache between her legs.
1212222211121121222121122222112212111221.title: Tragedy

1212222211121121222121122222112212111221.content:
Hinata could not recall a more miserable time in her life.

The events of yesterday had already been one heart-stopping moment after another. So when she saw Sasuke's electrifying fist pierce through her love, she just about thought her heart would finally give out. She had been just about ready to fall on her knees, shut down, and let fate decide he rend. She honestly didn't care what happened to herself at that point. But then, the red chakra that Ninata had used earlier came back in full force, and something wondrous happened: her wound, massive, gaping and fatal as it was, regenerated. Bones, muscles and organs that weren't supposed to heal were restored into near-perfect condition in a matter of minutes, as if they had been whole the entire time. But even so, Hinata feared the worst; she feared that her dear Ninata would shuffle away from her mortal coil at any moment, especially when she went limp and fainted.

Hinata had clutched her naked love with all her might, holding her close to make sure she still drew breath and emanated warmth, keeping a hand on her chest to count her heartbeats. She didn't recall anything else after that, only that she was eventually pulled away from Ninata by Anbu.

Relief only came to Hinata when she was assured that Ninata was would live. That she was fatigued, low on chakra, still had inflamed coils, but was stabilized, expected to make a full recovery, and wasn't going anywhere. At that moment, Hinata was sure that they were finally over the worst of it.

And then news of Kiba's condition reached her ears.

How the young Hyuga cried that day. She cried in the hospital. She cried in front of the Hokage. She cried as she was escorted home. She cried into her futon. She cried for so long, until her eyes were too red, sore and dry to keep crying. So she took a shower and sat miserably under the spray of water for nearly an hour, just so that she could continue to feel the sensation of hot water cascading down her face in tiny little rivulets.

Hinata ate nothing that evening. She never even left her apartment. After her shower, she just marched to her futon without bothering to put on any clothing and lied down.
